meta.description: The measure of how cold or hot the water is. Measured in celsius or fahrenheit.
meta.reason: Changes in temperature have an effect on biological activity. Each species has a preferred range to live at. Temperature effects water chemistry as well. For example, higher temperature can dissolve for minerals but hold less gas.

meta.description: The measure to determine the acidity of water.
meta.reason: pH is effected by changes in water chemistry and thus can be an important indicator. pH also affects solubility of metals, causing the water to be more toxic.

meta.description: The measure of oxygen in the water.
meta.reason: It is an important indicator of the water body’s ability to support aquatic life. Too little oxygen or too much can kill aquatic life.

meta.description: The measure of the ability of the water to pass electrical current.
meta.reason: Bodies of water usually have a base line range of conductivity. Significant changes in it may be indicators of a pollution event as conductivity is effected by salts and other compounds.

meta.description: The measure of dissolved salt content in water. Effects conductivity.
meta.reason: For organisms not used to changes in salinity, fluctuating levels can cause stress. Each living organism is adapted to the water body’s usual salinity range.

meta.description: The measure of the relative clarity of the water. Measured in NTU.
meta.reason: High turbidity affects light penetration. Particles also provide places for bacteria and other pollutants to attach to.
